awd_titl_txt: Research Security Training: The Importance of Disclosure
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will design and develop a training module about research security, and evaluate user perceptions of learning. Specifically, this module will focus on the importance of proper disclosure in the conduct of federally funded research. This project directly addresses the need to strengthen research security of U.S. government-supported research and development, per the National Security Presidential Memorandum – 33 (NSPM-33) and the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022. Dissemination and use of this training will better protect U.S. research interests from foreign and domestic risks and threats. The training module will be Internet-based, scalable, flexible, and widely accessible to researchers and stakeholders in various settings, including researchers with disabilities. This training module will increase awareness and understanding of the origins and requirements of the current disclosure process and articulate the importance and benefit of trust through transparency. It will also address several essential elements associated with the risk of non-disclosure when awarding participant organizations and individuals who willfully fail to disclose.  The development of the research security training module series is collaboratively funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Department of Energy (DOE), and the Department of Defense (DOD).

This research security training module, focused on the importance of proper disclosure of foreign collaborations, will be designed and developed in consultation with a Content Expert Group, which includes experts in research security across government. The module will employ the Situated Cognition Theory. Learners will be exposed to context-based case studies, interactive branching scenarios, and simulations of real-life disclosure scenarios in an academic research security setting. Following the initial design work and consultation, focus groups will be convened to evaluate the module's ease of use and measure the efficacy of the learning process. The evaluations will also allow learners to reflect on their perceptions of the module's content and online learning environment and delivery. The project team will assess the module's effectiveness via surveys, interviews, and group exchanges. The evaluation phase will include a compilation of Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) documentation of the learner's feedback during focus group testing and other course effectiveness testing methods. Following end user testing, evaluation, and revisions to the design, the module will be made available for dissemination to research security stakeholders, including university-based researchers, undergraduate, and graduate students, academic administrators, research security administrators, and researchers and staff in government agencies and national laboratories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Research Security Training: The Importance of Disclosure

Project Title: Research Security Training: The Importance of Disclosure

PI: Kevin R. Gamache, Ph.D., The Texas A&M University System

Co-PIs: Ivett A. Leyva, Ph.D., Texas A&M University, William Norris, Ph.D., Texas A&M University, Kay Wijkumar, Ph.D., Texas A&M University

Awardee: The Texas A&M University System

Award Number: NSF 2230530

PoP: December 1, 2023, to November 30, 2024

Award amount: $470808.00

Executive Summary 

This project created a 45-minute interactive multi-media training module on proper disclosure for the U.S. research enterprise that will play a foundational role in addressing the risks to maintaining the open and collaborative environment that has made the U.S. research community the best in the world.   The team that created the training included three faculty members from a Tier 1 research university, two chief research security officers from Tier 1 research universities, a former high-level compliance executive from a U.S. funding agency, and the CEO of a private firm engaged in research security training.

The module is fully ADA compliant and has been harmonized with three other teams developing related training modules that will address training issues associated with the requirements of implementing NSPM-3.  The team has incorporated extensive feedback from a broad representation of the research enterprise throughout the development process. 

Training scenario description:

The quiet hum of the research lab buzzed as Fatima Kiani, a young, ambitious post-doctoral researcher, tapped away at her keyboard. A frown creased her brow as she reread the email detailing the National Security Memorandum-33. "Harmonizing efforts...disclosure requirements...common forms..." Fatima muttered, the jargon washing over her. Research was her passion, not bureaucracy.

Feeling lost, Fatima contacted Emily Green, the Sponsored Research Administrator. "I'm supposed to fill out disclosure forms, but it all seems so complex," she confessed, frustration lacing her voice. Emily smiled reassuringly. "Don't worry, Fatima. This new policy aims to streamline things, not add burden. Let's take a look together."

Their conversation turned into a mini-lecture on Research Security. Emily explained how safeguarding sensitive research was crucial for national security, protecting intellectual property, and maintaining public trust. The concept clicked for Fatima. "So, disclosure isn't just paperwork, it's about protecting something bigger," she mused.

That's when Rachel Painter, the Vice-Chancellor for Research, walked by. Recognizing the opportunity, Emily introduced Fatima to the university's dedicated Research Security office. Rachel, impressed by Fatima's curiosity, extended an invitation: "We're launching a new training program called 'Research Security: The Importance of Disclosure.' Would you be interested in participating?"

The seed of interest was planted. Fatima envisioned understanding the requirements better and becoming a champion for Research Security within her team. With a nod, she accepted.

The training began with Fatima meeting a diverse group of researchers from various departments. The instructor, a seasoned security professional, used relatable scenarios to drive home the key points. A lively conversation unfolded as a simulated case study presented a researcher collaborating with a foreign entity – a seemingly innocent interaction that turned murky with undisclosed financial ties.

Fatima saw the ripple effect – how seemingly isolated actions could impact national security, damage research integrity, and jeopardize careers. The discussion shifted to real-life examples shared anonymously by experienced professionals. Cases of espionage, intellectual property theft, and compromised research resonated deeply, illustrating the gravity of non-disclosure.

By the end, Fatima emerged transformed. She understood the "why" behind the forms, the potential consequences of negligence, and the importance of proactive disclosure. More importantly, she felt empowered. Back in her lab, Fatima confidently briefed her team. Her newfound knowledge resonated as she explained the training, stressing the collective responsibility for safeguarding research. The initial apprehension melted away, replaced by understanding and commitment.

Fatima became a vocal advocate for Research Security as she continued her research journey. She mentored colleagues, clarified doubts, and encouraged open communication. The initial confusion had blossomed into a commitment to protecting her research and the integrity of the scientific ecosystem.

Training Module Conclusion:

This is not just Fatima's story; it's the narrative woven through countless training sessions, conversations, and personal journeys. It's a testament to the power of knowledge, shared responsibility, and the collective effort to protect research, one disclosure at a time. The story doesn't end here. It continues with every researcher who embraces the importance of disclosure, building trust, and safeguarding the vital wellspring of scientific discovery.
